… curled up on her couch, wearing lounge pants, {wi}quaffing{/wi} her third glass of wine …
… and in the chimney-corner, they all four {wi}quaffed{/wi}, and smoked, and prosed, and dozed, as they had done of old.
… {wi}quaffing{/wi} from massive steins of German beer while chatting it up with new friends.

dt: {bc}a small, freshwater, {d_link|lamellibranch|lamellibranch} mollusk ({it}Dreissena rostriformis bugensis{/it} synonym {it}Dreissena rostriformis{/it}) native to the {d_link|Dnieper|Dnieper:g} river and its tributaries that has been introduced into the Great Lakes and other waterways where it colonizes and clogs water intake pipes, competes with native fish for food, and disrupts {d_link|food webs|food web} by consuming phytoplankton

dt.t: The mussel-coated debris is unmistakable evidence of an event occurring silently and largely out of sight—the colonization of the Colorado River by the {wi}quagga mussel{/wi}, a fingernail-size Eurasian bivalve with an astonishing sex drive and a nasty reputation for causing economic and ecological havoc.

Less than four years after that reassuring report, {wi}quagga mussels{/wi} have gone from a rare find on the bottom of Lake Michigan to its dominant invasive mussel. Along the way, they have done what many invasion biologists thought would be impossible: They have nearly annihilated Lake Michigan's {d_link|zebra mussel|zebra mussel} population.

et: after {et_link|zebra mussel|zebra mussel}, the quagga mussel being less markedly striped, and hence comparable to the quagga in relation to the zebra
shortdef: a small, freshwater, lamellibranch mollusk (Dreissena rostriformis bugensis synonym Dreissena rostriformis) native to the Dnieper river and its tributaries that has been introduced into the Great Lakes and other waterways where it colonizes and clogs water intake pipes, competes with native fish for food, and disrupts food webs by consuming phytoplankton

dt: {bc}an extinct zebra ({it}Equus quagga quagga{/it}) of southern Africa that had brown and white stripes chiefly on the head and neck, reddish-brown to brown upper parts, and whitish belly, tail, and legs

dt.t: The last living {wi}quagga{/wi} died at the Amsterdam Zoo in 1883 …
The {wi}quagga{/wi}, a subspecies of zebra, was once common in South Africa, but European settlers hunted them to the extreme for the meat and fur.
Native to Ukraine, the {wi}quagga{/wi} now infests the [Great] lakes in even greater numbers than its invasive-species cousin the {d_link|zebra mussel|zebra mussel}.

quotes.t: {it}A Girl of the Limberlost{/it} is a Cinderella story whose wicked stepmother, in an interesting twist, is the heroine's real mother. She is a crazy person, deranged by grief for a husband who was sucked into a {qword}quagmire{/qword} before her eyes when she was pregnant with Elnora.

That was six months ago, when the Defense secretary laughingly dismissed the idea that Iraq was, or could turn into, a {qword}quagmire{/qword}. But as Rumsfeld sat down last Friday morning to face Sen. John McCain, who spent six years in a Vietnamese prison, no one was laughing.

State involvement will create a vast bioethical {qword}quagmire{/qword}. Even if everyone magically agrees that improving a child's memory is as valid as avoiding dyslexia, there will still be things taxpayers aren't ready to pay for—genes of unproven benefit, say, or alterations whose downsides may exceed the upside.

pt: {sc}strange{/sc} {sc}singular{/sc} {sc}unique{/sc} {sc}peculiar{/sc} {sc}eccentric{/sc} {sc}erratic{/sc} {sc}odd{/sc} {sc}quaint{/sc} {sc}outlandish{/sc} mean departing from what is ordinary, usual, or to be expected. {sc}strange{/sc} stresses unfamiliarity and may apply to the foreign, the unnatural, the unaccountable.
{sc}unique{/sc} implies singularity and the fact of being without a known parallel.

pt.t: a career {it}unique{/it} in the annals of science
the {it}peculiar{/it} status of America's First Lady

pt: {sc}eccentric{/sc} suggests a wide divergence from the usual or normal especially in behavior.
{sc}erratic{/sc} stresses a capricious and unpredictable wandering or deviating.
{sc}odd{/sc} applies to a departure from the regular or expected.
{sc}quaint{/sc} suggests an old-fashioned but pleasant oddness.
{sc}outlandish{/sc} applies to what is uncouth, bizarre, or barbaric.

quotes.t: Therefore, when the federal Constitutional Convention decided in 1787 that U.S. senators would be appointed by state legislatures rather than elected by the people at large, the drafters were actually placing the choice of U.S. senators in the control of state leaders who had met their states' highest qualifications for property and religion. Today, these property and religious qualifications are likely to strike us as {qword}quaint{/qword} historical oddities.

A lot can change in 25 years, and Yountville has gone from an also-ran on the Napa food-and-wine tourism scene to the focus of activity. The {qword}quaint{/qword} bed and breakfasts of yesterday have been replaced by upscale hotels and inns, and the village has become a mecca for top chefs.

Five minutes by ferry from the bustling concrete depths of Wall Street sits what could be a {qword}quaint{/qword} New England town: stately, collegiate buildings framed by tree-lined walkways where the wind rustles through aging oak trees.

pt: {sc}qualm{/sc} {sc}scruple{/sc} {sc}compunction{/sc} {sc}demur{/sc} mean a misgiving about what one is doing or going to do. {sc}qualm{/sc} implies an uneasy fear that one is not following one's conscience or better judgment.

{sc}demur{/sc} implies hesitation caused by objection to an outside suggestion or influence.

quotes.t: … the inevitable economic {qword}quandary{/qword} that faces a people in the transition from slavery to freedom, and especially those who make that change amid hate and prejudice, lawlessness and ruthless competition.

Williams's {qword}quandary{/qword} is not unlike that faced by other urban executives who have had to wrestle with a deeply rooted power structure. The problem is especially acute for African American mayors. They are expected to serve as sentries, protecting their cities' black communities and staving off so-called white encroachment.

For a sticky philosophical {qword}quandary{/qword}, the questions are pretty simple: am I a clerk charged with selling college degrees or am I involved in a more meaningful experience? Part of me says that no argument is more worthy of my attention.

shortdef: a state of perplexity or doubt

dt.t: The Fed has already done plenty with its unique stimulus program of {wi}quantitative easing{/wi}, or QE, the $85 billion-a-month purchase of bonds and mortgage-backed assets that started pumping cash into the system in 2008.

Speculation is increasing that in an effort to stimulate the sluggish economy, the central bank will soon announce additional {wi}quantitative easing{/wi}, the strategy of buying long-term assets like Treasury bonds to lower long-term interest rates.
Since 2000, the Bank of Japan has progressively increased the intensity of its {wi}quantitative easing{/wi} programs in response to stagnant growth and failures in its banking system.

shortdef: a set of government policies that may be implemented by a central bank to increase the money supply in the economy —abbreviation QE

dt: {bc}a property of a set of subatomic particles whereby a quantum characteristic (such as {d_link|spin|spin:2} or {d_link|momentum|momentum}) of one particle is directly and immediately correlated with the equivalent characteristic of the others regardless of separation in space

dt.t: In {wi}quantum entanglement{/wi}, subatomic particles maintain a relationship—for instance, vibrating when the other vibrates—even when separated and even if they are at great distances from each other.

{wi}Quantum entanglement{/wi} occurs when two systems share a common quantum mechanical state. Such systems also share a common fate, even if they become physically quite separated. The results of a measurement performed on one will determine the results of future measurements on the second.

shortdef: a property of a set of subatomic particles whereby a quantum characteristic (such as spin or momentum) of one particle is directly and immediately correlated with the equivalent characteristic of the others regardless of separation in space

dt: {bc}to refrain from any contact with other individuals for a period of time (such as two weeks) during the outbreak of a contagious disease usually by remaining in one's home and limiting contact with family members

To reduce transmission of a contagious disease during an outbreak, individuals are typically asked by health officials to self-quarantine following known contact with an infectious person or after returning from a region where cases of the disease are widely reported.

dt.t: As the coronavirus spreads across the country, thousands of people who may have been exposed to the virus through travel abroad or contact with an infected person have been asked to {wi}self-quarantine{/wi} for two weeks to help contain the outbreak.

Senator Ted Cruz (R-TX) announced on Sunday evening that he will be {wi}self-quarantining{/wi} at home in Texas after learning that he had a {ldquo}brief conversation and a handshake{rdquo} with someone at the Conservative Political Action Conference who later tested positive for the coronavirus.

utxt.t: [Sam] Page said the woman's father did not comply with the health department's instructions and left {wi}self-quarantine{/wi} to take another daughter to a school function on Saturday.
{wi}Self-quarantines{/wi} only work if people are willing to inconvenience themselves for the public good.

shortdef: to refrain from any contact with other individuals for a period of time (such as two weeks) during the outbreak of a contagious disease usually by remaining in one's home and limiting contact with family members

pt: {sc}quarrel{/sc} {sc}wrangle{/sc} {sc}altercation{/sc} {sc}squabble{/sc} mean a noisy dispute usually marked by anger. {sc}quarrel{/sc} implies heated verbal contention, stressing strained or severed relations which may persist beyond the contention.
{sc}wrangle{/sc} suggests undignified and often futile disputation with a noisy insistence on differing opinions.
{sc}altercation{/sc} implies fighting with words as the chief weapon, although it may also connote blows.
{sc}squabble{/sc} stresses childish and unseemly dispute over petty matters, but it need not imply bitterness or anger.

pt: The adjective {it}queer{/it} is now most frequently applied with its meanings relating to sexual orientation and/or gender identity, as outlined at sense 2 above. When these meanings were developing in the early 20th century, they were strongly pejorative, echoing the negative connotations of the word's older meanings, which included {ldquo}weird,{rdquo} {ldquo}suspicious,{rdquo} and {ldquo}unwell.{rdquo} But the adjective today is commonly used as a positive or neutral self-descriptor, and also has wide use as a neutral broad descriptor for a large and varied group of people.

pt.t: Contemporary Black activism has also largely been informed by the concurrent agitation surrounding trans and {wi}queer{/wi} rights …

dt.t: And knowledge of [his identity as a gay man] opens a path to consider how and to what degree his art {wi}queered{/wi}—to use a term from academic theory—received versions of American culture: questioned their validity, revealed their contradictions, turned them inside out.

The term {d_link|genderqueer|genderqueer} was originally coined in the 1990s to describe those who "{wi}queered{/wi}" gender by defying oppressive gender norms in the course of their binary-defying activism.

What struck me about this book when I read it nearly two decades ago was how she {wi}queered{/wi} the lives of black women who depend on one another to survive, who love each other intimately, and who exist at the intersections of race, gender, class and sexuality. It is a raw and complex narrative about coming into one's self, becoming more familiar and at ease with all of the parts of one's self, and it is a powerful accounting of a black lesbian facing head-on her own adversities.

What struck me about this book when I read it nearly two decades ago was how she {wi}queered{/wi} the lives of black women who depend on one another to survive, who love each other intimately, and who exist at the intersections of race, gender, class and sexuality. dt.t: Illocutionary acts … such as stating, {wi}questioning{/wi}, promising, or commanding.
… serious {wi}questionings{/wi} of the relation between art and life …

quotes.t: The Tiong Bahru hawker center in Singapore might well be my favorite place in the world to start the day. I remember vividly my first visit: I arrived jetlagged and hungry at seven in the morning to find vendors stir-frying greens in gigantic woks, sending up whooshes of smoke fragrant with garlic. Long {qword}queues{/qword} of businessmen and construction workers and families who likely lived in the nearby housing projects snaked from the cash register of each stall.

Around the time the Soviet Union ceased to exist, I was waiting in the entry {qword}queue{/qword} at Fiumicino Airport in Rome when I noticed a party of several dozen young Russian girls being fast-tracked past a freshly opened control window.

But many more people deserve the Nobel than get it. Krauss should've gotten it years ago. Though by now so many other discoveries have been made that he's farther down in an ever increasing {qword}queue{/qword}.

The World's Food Fair, Boston. October 1896. Admission: 25 cents. Huge crowds throng the Mechanics Hall convention center. Women {qword}queue{/qword} up for free samples from 200 different vendors: cereals, gelatins, extracts, candy, and custards.

quotes.t: My hostess told me she had some records I might like to hear and she called for {qword}quiet{/qword} in the room. People sat down on the floor in groups, sharing bottles of wine and slivovitz. The host put the record on a windup record player and Lester Young's saxophone yowled out of the silence.
When my parents needed peace and {qword}quiet{/qword}, they didn't put me in front of the television to watch a "Baby Einstein" video; they plopped me in a chair to watch my mom do housework or cook.

et: Middle English {it}quiet, quiete,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}quiete,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}quiēt-, quiēs{/it} "repose, sleep, rest, peaceful conditions," going back to Indo-European {it}*k{sup}w{/sup}i̯eh{inf}1{/inf}-ti-,{/it} noun derivative of a verbal base {it}*k{sup}w{/sup}i̯eh{inf}1{/inf}-{/it} "have a rest," whence Avestan {it}š́iiā-{/it} "be glad," Old Church Slavic {it}počijǫ, počiti{/it} "to have a rest" (causative {it}pokojǫ, pokoiti{/it} "to calm, quiet"), Armenian han{it}geaw{/it} "has rested," and (from deverbal {it}*k{sup}w{/sup}i̯eh{inf}1{/inf}-to-{/it}) Avestan {it}š́iiāta-{/it} "peaceful, happy," Old Persian {it}šiyāta-,{/it} Latin {it}quiētus{/it} "at rest, {et_link|quiet:2|quiet:2}"
shortdef: the quality or state of being quiet : tranquility

quotes.t: I interviewed Virginia, who is totally blind, in a small local library. Walking with her guide dog, this young-looking woman arrived soon after I came in. We found a {qword}quiet{/qword} corner to sit and talk while her dog settled beside her chair. At forty-three, Virginia was used to telling her story and found time for our interview in her busy travel schedule. She had just returned from San Francisco where she had spoken at the California Academy of Sciences and was about to leave for Montreal, Canada, to conduct workshops in diversity awareness.

Breakfast at the Royal Bombay Yacht Club, a members-only institution founded in the city now called Mumbai in 1846 by British colonial officers, is a meal of {qword}quiet{/qword} elegance. The second-story veranda looks out over a small garden and, beyond that, the Gateway of India and the Taj Mahal Hotel. Outside is the tumult of horse-drawn carriages, touts, and taxis. Inside is peaceful stillness, broken only by the sounds of crunched-on toast and rustling newspapers.

Attributing their behaviors to their personal dispositions, we decide Julie is shy and Jack is outgoing. Because people do have enduring personality traits, such attributions are sometimes valid. However, we often overestimate the influence of personality and underestimate the influence of situations. In class, Jack may be as {qword}quiet{/qword} as Julie. Catch Julie at a party and you may hardly recognize your {qword}quiet{/qword} classmate.
One change I notice is that I get sleepy earlier than I used to, sometimes by 8:30 or 9 if I am having a {qword}quiet{/qword} evening at home.

et: Middle English {it}quyet, quyete, quiete,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French & Middle French {it}quiete,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}quiētus{/it} "at rest, inactive, peaceful" {ma}{mat|quiet:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: free from noise or uproar : still
making or involving no noise or very little noise
tending to speak very little : not loquacious
in a quiet manner

quotes.t: When she walked down the hall past his classroom, the sounds of chaos came over the frosted-glass pane above the door. She had taken to making random visits; the sight of her in the doorway {qword}quieted{/qword} the kids.

Clemens had few questions to answer about Piazza. The beanball and broken bat from 2000, and the Mets' tepid retaliation last season, were memories. And since Clemens recorded his 300th victory on June 13, the buzz around him has {qword}quieted{/qword}.
Even with that, Presser was so scared that he fled to Florida and moved from hotel to hotel till the gang war {qword}quieted{/qword} down, with his side on top.

quotes.t: I interviewed Virginia, who is totally blind, in a small local library. Walking with her guide dog, this young-looking woman arrived soon after I came in. We found a {qword}quiet{/qword} corner to sit and talk while her dog settled beside her chair. At forty-three, Virginia was used to telling her story and found time for our interview in her busy travel schedule. She had just returned from San Francisco where she had spoken at the California Academy of Sciences and was about to leave for Montreal, Canada, to conduct workshops in diversity awareness.

Breakfast at the Royal Bombay Yacht Club, a members-only institution founded in the city now called Mumbai in 1846 by British colonial officers, is a meal of {qword}quiet{/qword} elegance. The second-story veranda looks out over a small garden and, beyond that, the Gateway of India and the Taj Mahal Hotel. Outside is the tumult of horse-drawn carriages, touts, and taxis. Inside is peaceful stillness, broken only by the sounds of crunched-on toast and rustling newspapers.

Attributing their behaviors to their personal dispositions, we decide Julie is shy and Jack is outgoing. Because people do have enduring personality traits, such attributions are sometimes valid. However, we often overestimate the influence of personality and underestimate the influence of situations. In class, Jack may be as {qword}quiet{/qword} as Julie. Catch Julie at a party and you may hardly recognize your {qword}quiet{/qword} classmate.
One change I notice is that I get sleepy earlier than I used to, sometimes by 8:30 or 9 if I am having a {qword}quiet{/qword} evening at home.

dt.t: This is the {wi}quintessential{/wi} Los Angeles restaurant, casual but never frumpy, lively but not overheated …
Marx was the {wi}quintessential{/wi} intellectual, remarkably detached from the real world.

utxt.t: It is commonly accepted … that the rocking chair was an American invention, perhaps the most {wi}quintessentially{/wi} American furniture form ever invented.
There's no occupation more {wi}quintessentially{/wi} macho than that of private detective.

pt: {sc}imaginary{/sc} {sc}fanciful{/sc} {sc}visionary{/sc} {sc}fantastic{/sc} {sc}chimerical{/sc} {sc}quixotic{/sc} mean unreal or unbelievable. {sc}imaginary{/sc} applies to something which is fictitious and purely the product of one's imagination.
{sc}fanciful{/sc} suggests the free play of the imagination.
{sc}visionary{/sc} stresses impracticality or incapability of realization.
{sc}fantastic{/sc} implies incredibility or strangeness beyond belief.
{sc}quixotic{/sc} implies a devotion to romantic or chivalrous ideals unrestrained by ordinary prudence and common sense.

quotes.t: In … an earnest book-length essay of neo-Victorian public-mindedness that deplores the "nasty, knowing abuse" that the author would have us fear contaminates too much American humor lately, David Denby, a movie critic for {it}The New Yorker{/it}, sets for himself what has to be one of the most {qword}quixotic{/qword} projects that a moral reformer can undertake.

The history of biblical oil prospecting is filled with {qword}quixotic{/qword} quests and colorful characters, starting with Welsie Hancock, a wealthy California man who in the 1960s dreamed that Jesus told him he would find black gold in the Holy Land. He sunk his entire fortune into two dry holes.

Mumey had announced his candidacy as an independent in the partisan election, which meant that he needed 2,300 signatures of registered voters in order to get on the ballot in the fall. It seemed a {qword}quixotic{/qword} adventure, given the small size of Celebration and Mumey's lack of name recognition outside the town.

dt: {bc}a standard English-language typewriter or computer keyboard on which the first six letters of the second row are {it}q{/it}, {it}w{/it}, {it}e{/it}, {it}r{/it}, {it}t{/it}, and {it}y{/it}

dt.t: {wi}QWERTY{/wi} may not have had the most sensible keyboard arrangement, but it had the advantage that it had been out longer than most other designs. Throughout the 1880s, typewriters with a variety of keyboard layouts were sold, but in the 1890s the market moved more and more toward {wi}QWERTY{/wi}, and by the first decade of the twentieth century it had taken over.

The {wi}QWERTY keyboard{/wi}, a central artifact of the information economy, was arranged in the 1870s with a deliberately awkward pattern of letters to slow typists down so they wouldn't jam the innards of early typing machines.

et: from the first six letters in the second row of the keyboard
shortdef: a standard English-language typewriter or computer keyboard on which the first six letters of the second row are q, w, e, r, t, and y
